case_vignette:
A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. Aside from occasional lower back pain in the last couple of years, he feels well. He had a right-sided myocardial infarction 4 years ago. Currently, he has no shortness of breath and has no anginal symptoms. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but stopped smoking 10 years ago and does not drink alcohol. His pulse is 59/min, and his blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals 1+ lower extremity edema. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation show no abnormalities. There is no lymphadenopathy. His laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 13.2 g/dL and serum protein of 10.1 g/dL. ECG shows known Q wave abnormalities unchanged since the last ECG one year ago. A serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis?

Physical examination reveals 1+ lower extremity edema. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation show no abnormalities. There is no lymphadenopathy. His laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 13.2 g/dL and serum protein of 10.1 g/dL. ECG shows known Q wave abnormalities unchanged since the last ECG one year ago. A serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis?

I occasionally have lower back pain, but otherwise, I feel well.
How old are you and what is your gender?
I am 71 years old and I am a man.
Have you noticed any changes in your urination, like frequency, color, or pain?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in my urination.

I do not have information about my family's medical history to share.
Have you experienced any recent or unexplained weight loss, fever, or night sweats?
No, I have not experienced any recent or unexplained weight loss, fever, or night sweats.
Have you had any issues with numbness, tingling, or weakness in your legs or feet?
No, I haven't had any issues with numbness, tingling, or weakness in my legs or feet.

Yes, my recent blood work showed a hemoglobin level of 13.2 g/dL and a serum protein level of 10.1 g/dL.

I don't have past information on my serum protein levels, but my current level is high at 10.1 g/dL, and a serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation was performed as part of my evaluation.
What were the results of the serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation?
The specific results of the serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation have not been detailed to me.

No, my doctor has not mentioned any specific concerns about a type of blood cell or suggested a bone marrow biopsy.

Yes, the serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation is a step towards evaluating for plasma cell disorders.
Final Diagnosis: Multiple Myeloma
